comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: The first named ship should be "AUSTRALASIAN". This correct name is visible on the bow of the ship through the zoom feature available at the Persistent URL. We also know that this event occurred at Circular Quay on 3 March, 1885. For reference, see this plate from the Illustrated London News: www.old-print.com/cgi-bin/category.cgi?item=MAR1042211# and this site: www.firstbattalion.au.com/Our Heritage.htm

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Of course it is understood that the original caption is retained for historical value.

So, you would not be inclined to add a note to your catalogue information at the persistent URL correctly identifying the ships then?

Would not such a notation assist researchers seeking a photograph of the actual AUSTRALASIAN?

[ Note added 2 May 2013: For some reason the comments by the Powerhouse Museum to which I am responding here has been deleted.  The comment by the Powerhouse Museum immediately preceding this one was something to the effect that the caption of this photo "Departure of troopships 'Australian' and 'Iberia' for the Soudan" has been retained because it was on the original plate negative.  I'm just adding this note for clarity, because it helps to make sense of how I begin this comments.]

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: See newly posted related image here: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2633058828/

comment.author: 11946814@N02
comment._content: Hola, soy el administrador de un grupo llamado AQUELLOS MAGNÍFICOS NAVÍOS y nos encantaría agregar tu excelente fotografía al grupo.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
The Australasian, and the ship behind it, the Iberia are at the Orient Line Wharf.

This photograph is in the collection of the Australian War Memorial at P00640.001, and it states at the AWM "original in Mitchell Library".

However you can't get any more original than the glass plate negative in the collection of the Powerhouse Museum.

comment.author: 30874866@N03
comment._content: Wow I am really happy to find this picture. Sometimes I feel the New South Wales contingent in the Sudan is an overlooked part of our history.

comment.author: 32958677@N08
comment._content: Ci farebbe piacere avere la tua foto nel gruppo "La mia prima foto su Flickr - My first photo on Flickr"

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Not only does 'zoomify' allow us to see the ship's name but 3 blokes sitting on the peaked roof of one building and, just below, reflections in a puddle!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Charles Bayliss was at the other end of the wharf - cas.awm.gov.au/item/P05711.001

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read all about it (as if it was yesterday) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13579216 NB - continues over to page 8 with very full details including the three flags on top of Hill Clarke Co., the ships on the other side of Circular Quay, and a fatal collision between 'Iberia' and 'Nemesis' near South Head.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia - That Sydney Morning Herald report from Wednesday 4 March 1885 is a masterpiece of factual reporting.  The style of writing is old fashioned of course, but the amount of information is astonishing.
